Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2020 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (CNS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports student travel to attend the 2020 IEEE Conference on Computer and Network Security (CNS 2020) held June 29-July 1, 2020. The IEEE CNS Conference is a premier venue for communications and network security researchers to present new research results in this domain. This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.<br/><br/>This grant provides travel support to encourage participation in the 2020 IEEE Communications and Network Security Conference by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Criteria for selection include evidence of a serious interest in the field, as demonstrated by research output, coursework and/or project experience. Organizers encourage participation of women and students from other under-represented groups.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original goal of this project was to provide student travel grants to support students attending the IEEE CNS 2020 conference, which is a premier forum for security researchers, practitioners, policy makers, and users to exchange ideas and provides an ideal venue for students to engage in academic enrichment, enhance their professional development, and expand their networking opportunities.

Unfortunately, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, both IEEE CNS 2020 and 2021 were transitioned to virtual formats, and no fund was spent on student travel grant. Given the unique advantages of face-to-face interactions, the project was extended twice to allow us to repurpose the funds to support student participation in IEEE CNS 2022.

IEEE CNS 2022 took place in a hybrid format from October 3 to 5, 2022, in Austin, TX. This dual modality gave attendees the flexibility to participate either in person or virtually.

By the application deadline, we received a total of 16 from U.S.-based students, including 5 applications from female students. The number of applications was lower than in previous years, likely due to the hybrid format of the conference.  Out of the 16 applications, the award selection committee selected 15 students to receive student travel grants including 5 female students. 


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Rui Zhang
